channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: How Much for a Latte? Even High-Flying Starbucks Is Suffering
Weekend Watch: Spike Lee gets real about racism
item.description:
[rebelmouse-proxy-image https://www.theblaze.com/media-library/weekend-watch-spike-lee-gets-real-about-racism.jpg?id=52163461&width=1200&height=800&coordinates=0,0,202,0 crop_info="%7B%22image%22%3A%20%22https%3A//www.theblaze.com/media-library/weekend-watch-spike-lee-gets-real-about-racism.jpg%3Fid%3D52163461%26width%3D1200%26height%3D800%26coordinates%3D0%2C0%2C202%2C0%22%7D" expand=1]

‚ÄúEveryone's a Little Bit Racist‚Äù goes a jaunty tune from the 2004 Broadway hit ‚ÄúAvenue Q.‚Äù It's funny because it's true.

Humans are by nature tribal. We tend to mistrust and stereotype outsiders. Acknowledging this can relieve tension and lead to honest, productive conversation.

Spike Lee has spent his career sparking such conversations, nowhere more effectively than in his 1989 film ‚ÄúDo the Right Thing.‚Äù Depicting the simmering racial tension of one hot summer day in Brooklyn, Lee's film at first seems to side mainly with its black characters.

As it progresses, however, Lee makes sure we also see the complicated humanity of their white antagonists. They, like everyone else in the film, are just trying to get by and live their lives. They have more important things to worry about than race.

One scene in particular captures Lee's ‚Äúwe're-all-in-this-together‚Äù approach: different characters ‚Äì the black protagonist (played by Lee himself), a Korean grocer, a white cop, a Puerto Rican neighbor ‚Äì address the camera with rapid-fire racial slurs. The creativity and fluency with which each character denigrates another race makes it funny; the genuine anger behind it makes it uncomfortable.


When the tension finally explodes in violence and destruction (which can't help but remind us of the summer of 2020, if not our current campus unrest), ‚ÄúDo the Right Thing‚Äù again chooses to unsettle. Nobody has proven a point; nobody has ‚Äúwon.‚Äù The characters, like the audience, are left to ponder the seemingly insurmountable human impulse to scapegoat and turn strangers into enemies.

item.title: Biden brings up Islamophobia amid the worst antisemitism outbreak in decades
item.description: President Biden, while condemning anti-Israel violence at college campuses across the country, brought up Islamophobia despite the worst antisemitism outbreak in decades.

item.title: The Leftist Election Interference Crew
Harvard Commencement Speaker Published Editorial Likening Israel to Hitler
item.description:
Harvard's commencement speaker, media CEO Maria Ressa, published an editorial that compared Israel after Hamas's October 7 terrorist attack to Nazi Germany and accused the Jewish state of "targeting" news reporters in an "unprecedented attack on journalist safety."

The post Harvard Commencement Speaker Published Editorial Likening Israel to Hitler appeared first on Washington Free Beacon.

item.title: VP Stakes: Trump meeting with potential running mates this weekend
item.description: Donald Trump moves from the courtroom in New York City to the banquet rooms in South Florida on Friday, as he headlines a gathering of top Republican donors and teams up with potential running mates.

item.title: Trump Wants To Influence Who Runs Elections in Miami Dade
Joe Biden Is 2024's Chaos Candidate
item.description:
Back in 2015, Jeb Bush warned his fellow Republicans that his billionaire rival for the GOP presidential nomination was "a chaos candidate. And he'd be a chaos president." Republican primary voters ignored him. Trump won the nomination and the presidency. His years in office were tumultuous, to say the least. Yet today's electorate views the instability that Trump brought to Washington differently than the disorder that Biden unleashed at home and abroad. Once there was a single "chaos president." Now there are two.

The post Joe Biden Is 2024's Chaos Candidate appeared first on Washington Free Beacon.

item.title: FLASHBACK: Biden confidante made revealing admission about Obama DOJ in unearthed interview
item.description: A former U.S. Senator and longtime Biden ally said in 2012 that the Department of Justice is "full of Biden people" renewing concerns about the departments impartiality.

item.title: Which states could have abortion on the ballot in 2024?
item.description: It is not yet clear how many states will vote in November on measures to preserve abortion access following the 2022 decision by the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn Roe v. Wade.
